ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 10 hours/week
6-7 hours per week
1 hour
2-3 hours/week
3hrs
.5hr
N/a
3 hours/week
3 hours.
5-7 hours/week
5 hours
Around 3 hours.
I spent 2-3 hours per week on average during the course.
3 to 5 depending on the case for the week.
4 hours
2 - 3 hours
2-5 for doing the readings (per week)3-10 when there was homework (per homework)15-20 to do the midterm (once)10-15 to do the final (once)
3-4 hours.
5 hours
5 hours
3-4 hours
1h
3-4 on an average week, but the two take-home exams took much more time than any other course. Around 12 hours for the midterm and 6 for the final.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Very good

Strengths:-on the onset, seems very applicable to decisions you might make in a healthcare setting-goes through a good range of probability and excel modeling for those who haven't studied it beforeWeaknesses:-after taking the class, it feels like the topics/decisions covered were much more applicable to a policy setting and less relevant for healthcare management--> improve by adding more examples of decisions that healthcare administrators or consultants might make

The instructor is so great: smart, entertaining, knowledgable, but the course itself is largely driven by his lectures alone. The homework is not graded, so there is no feedback on assignments no supplemental work for the course beyond a once-a-week lecture. It is really, really critical to beef up this course, perhaps creating a weekly section with more rigorous homework assignments.
Interesting class
Interesting and well-taught.
Overall good class, but I definitely expected to learn a lot more. It didn't help that the lectures were in Winslow.

Strengths- material is very interesting and I'd like to learn more about it in a different way. Weaknesses- I don't think the lectures added much to the course, and it was difficult to figure out how to learn the material independently. More practice problems or a different class format (maybe a review section?) might help...

The course was good. There were so many disruptions at the end of the semester that it felt a little disjointed, but I think I learned a good background on the subject. I wish we had more examples for each of the topics because it was all too new for me to have questions about a topic so that I could understand it more. I also wish that it was not as focused on clinical decision making and wish it was more about different policy or intervention choices, it would just make it easier to know how to do analysis in many different situations.

It was a good introduction to the topic. I would have liked to read and really deeply discuss a couple more papers from the recent literature that really explored the topics (and maybe a good, recent review paper of cost effectiveness research in public health). The course moved a bit slowly for my tastes and I think this course is ideal for a kind of final project instead of final in which one could actually do some kind of research, playing with MCMC, playing with published data, or something else. I would have also been curious to hear more about the intersection of cost effectiveness research (the "dry numbers"), human psychology/behavioral economics ("reality"/"perceptions"), and actual policy decisions (eg social welfare functions, how the different sides are integrated, how policy is actually made, and what the role for cost-effectiveness research is for academics and policy makers).
strength: interesting topics, very practicalweakness: didn't see any
Good class, but feel like I didn't have a class the second half of the semester.
strengths: awesome course. very applicable to most areas of public healthweaknesses: rushed material due to storm
strengths: very organized and applicableweakness: more problem sets to work on, more homework

Since this is now a required class for HPM, it is needs to be restructured so it caters to the HPM students. While the concepts remain the same, I am not interested in clinical/medical decision making and the reading is too dense to understand if it doesn't have a policy application.The class needs to have more TFs and it would be better with a discussion section. The instructor doesn't really teach the material. Therefore, if you don't have enough knowledge to teach yourself, you are lost and in that case, it has no value. If a class is going to be required, the program needs to commit to making sure it is well taught and suited for its students.
N/a

The topics discussed during the course were very motivating and well prepared. Each class included examples and additional resources. The paste of the class was rather fast and instructor often engaged students into discussions.In my opinion the midterm and final exams were much more difficult as compared to examples provided during lectures.
very good skills learned,need more application of those skills during class

I was an active listener in the course, but I really struggled with the midterm. This made me re-evaluate what I actually did learn from the instructor. When I was going over his slides and my notes, I found that I had to re-read all of the readings to get a sense of what I learned. I am not sure why that was for the midterm, but the final was better.

Strength: the course material is very interesting and unique. To do well in the course requires good quantitative and logic skills. It is a very good practice.Weekness: the mid-term is very hard, which I don't know it is necessary or not. Also, on classesV2 within the folder for class notes, the material is a little disorganized. It will be much better if the professor include unified file names.
Very passive, also not what I imagined cost effectiveness to be given I worked in the area for years; too theoretical and math based. Would have preferred a more financial perspective.

I appreciate the fact that the homework was not graded for correctness; but rather it was graded for completion/effort. Since the homework problems were only discussed after the homework was due, this homework policy was appreciated.
Strengths:1. Skills based class- the content covered in the course is very applicable to real world problems2. Despite being a complex course, the content is very well structured
So, so hard, almost impossibly hard. Felt more like a struggle than an invigorating challenge.

This was an awesome course! The use of case write-ups to discuss the material is one of its strengths. Overall, no major weaknesses, but I think a couple additional sessions might have been helpful to cover all the material.

The course had a reasonable work load, and I enjoyed the weekly homework assignments. I liked the format of the course, which involved self-learning and application of concepts followed by clarification and explanation by the instructor.

This is a great course for students who want to learn about cost-effectiveness analysis or medical decision-making. The concepts are taught in an enjoyable, interactive way, and Dr. Paltiel really makes an effort to show the utility of these concepts. That said, this class is only an introduction and really does not go into depth on any of these concepts. In addition, the class can move somewhat slowly at times, but the information is useful and it is a really enjoyable class to attend. I really enjoyed this class.
This course provided an excellent overview of cost effectiveness analysis in both methodology and theory/practicality of the methods. It was extremely interesting and useful for any student.
I don't have much criticism. Loved this course.
Great!
The midterm was too hard.
It's a very interesting and helpful course.The professor is a very good lecturer.
Excellent introduction to cost-effectiveness analysis.

Interesting lectures and material which seems like they will apply to my future career, however too much emphasis on clinical aspects of CEA and not many PH policy/CEA scenarios discussed or presented. As a requirement for HPM students, this course should have a closer connection to policy issues.
This course is amazing. It was a lot of work but it was interesting and I learned a lot of things that I think will be good for my professional career.
I feel some methods to do the cost-effectiveness will be very useful in practice
Great course. Good introduction to decision analysis

Strengths:Dr. Paltiel is a great speaker.He really cares about teaching.He provides a great explanation of the principles behind cost-effectiveness and medical decision making as well as really interesting examples of studies that employ the principles.Weaknesses:None.

-Lectures were clear-Readings were helpful-The class moved a little slowly and I believe more material could have been covered. Maybe an advanced second course could be offered in this topic-I felt like I gained enough knowledge to be able to grasp the cost-effectiveness literature, but not enough to do cost-effectiveness research-Midterm questions were good, but the way the points were distributed were kind of strange (i.e. taking off almost all the points on the question for a small error, and only taking off a few points for a bigger error on another question)
The course provides a strong foundation for decision trees, cost effective analysis, etc. The lectures support the self-learning required to master the subject.

While the second half of the course was cut shorter due to several class cancellations, it felt that the second half was the material we should have covered in more depth. While decision trees and analysis seem foundational, for future health policy work additional time spent on CE would have been extremely helpful.

Strengths--I liked that we did the homework before we actually learned the material because--although it took too long--after struggling to figure out how to do it, I learned from my mistakes. I like that they provided us with "student notes" for each class aside from the power points. The professor made the material sound fun even though it is so dry.Weaknesses--I would have liked to receive feedback in our homework assignments and not just get a grade from them. I did not like the instructions for the third question in the midterm. It seemed unfair to have such a tricky question and be told not to spend too much time on it.To improve--change the lecture time, from 5 to 7 it is very tiring to pay attention through it.

The course is very helpful for us to learn the basic concepts and principles of cost effectiveness analysisã The instructor is very helpful and has a very special teaching style. And he is very sensitive of students' reaction and can give a response very soon.

This course was simply excellent. It introduced all of the tools in cost-effectiveness analysis and decision making that public health professionals need to evaluate evidence and an intro for using it in research.I wish we had more help in applying some of the models, even if its just as an introduction to using excel for this type of analysis

I found this course to be one of the most valuable I've taken at Yale. I can see some of the issues that other people have had with this class, but I found it to be well organized, interesting, and useful.
Great lecturer. Interesting and valuable topics

This course is a great introduction to cost effectiveness analysis and policy modeling more generally. It will help you think about a number of issues like an analyst, and give you a greater appreciation for and ability to read analysis based on these methods. It also does a great job tempering these ideas with an understanding that cost-effectiveness is not and should not be the only driving force behind decision-making, and the exams and problem sets push students to really think about those larger issues while working through analytic methods.
I like this class. Learn about cost-effective analysis although I'm not sure about its applicability in my career.
Super interesting material, and the professor really makes it come alive.
Strengths: Great topic and tool to learn; Excellent instructorWeaknesses: Would be great if we could learn how to use software along with the theory
great course
My favorite course. My favorite professor. Awesome.
The course was very good. Lectures were engaging and applied the the material to public health examples. The midterm exam was very long, but the final was much more reasonable.

Best class of the termOften had time to start and finish the homework the day of class. This still left plenty of time to understand the concepts.Amazing class and it is very relevant.The Prof, David Paltiel is able to take a possibly difficult and dry subject and make is exciting and very easy to understand.You definitely get the tools you need to expand on this knowledge-set later on.Even if you go to class tired, listening to the prof speak will wake you up.Weakness:wish we had more practice problems
I enjoyed this course and the material that was presented.

Strengths: Dynamic instructor, excellent TA, some very interesting examples and applications of the material in-course. For the most part, the instructor addressed students requests and responded to student input on the course.Weaknesses: The instructor catered to students who understand the material well, often leaving the rest of us behind during lectures and DEFINITELY on the midterm. The midterm was the single most difficult exam I have taken at YSPH, and did not accurately reflect the material that I felt I had learned. For me, past about week 5 I benefited very little from going to lecture as the material was presented very quickly and often in a confusing manner. The texts were sometimes helpful and sometimes not. The course could benefit from a textbook (or multiple textbooks if need be), as students need something more comprehensive to refer to than single articles.
- Little background or additional practice is provided
This was a good course, but I feel like it should have prereqs (as it did before). I felt unprepared for the course simply because I did not have any statistical background.

The cases were interesting and helpful for practicing what we learned in class. The lecture slides were very informative and easy to refer back to.Having an additional exam or more cases would have been helpful.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: A David Paltiel  Excellent

Instructor: A David Paltiel  David was great. He was funny and kept our attention spans despite the late hour and length of the class.He was always encouraging us to ask questions and engage with the topics, so no question was too silly.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He's wonderful. The course is just OK. I wanted more out of it, but a single lecture once-a-week meant we didn't have much time with him and we never saw the TA.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He is a funny guy!
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Exceptional
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Engaging, responsive to student feedback, very funny!
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Enthusiastic Professor, very knowledgeable.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Definitely engaging and very knowledgeable...class format makes it difficult to interact, though. Some of the lectures were interesting, but they didn't follow the reading so at times my mind would drift and I'd miss something. Having slides posted prior to class to follow along in class and take notes would have been helpful.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He is an entertaining and accommodating teacher really receptive to questions. I would just add more examples so students get a better rounded understanding of topics.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Great professor. Really engaging and very open to talking with students and receiving feedback. Takes a potentially dry subject and makes it more interesting and engaging than one might imagine.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  strength: he's just AWESOMEweakness: didn't see any
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He's great, very engaging in class.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  very passionate, great instructor, sensitive to feedback.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very engaging and attentive to students
Instructor: A David Paltiel  N/a
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel is an excellent lecturer, very animated, funny and engaging. He knows the subject matter very well and provides many interesting digressions.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Good teachermay be too busy

Instructor: A David Paltiel  He is a very entertaining and thorough professor. I wish for lectures that we did not go over the homework, that we could have the slides before the lecture. It is hard to follow on Excel, if we don't have that material in front of us. Trying to go over it before the midterm/final takes way, way too much time.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel is very responsible, and he knows very well what he is teaching.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Strengths:1. Funny!2. Very, very knowledgeable3. Passionate about cost effectiveness and decision making4. Very approachable
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He is wonderful, but moves so fast I fell behind a lot
Instructor: A David Paltiel  What a great instructor! Definitely one of the most engaging teachers I've had at the school. I wouldn't change a thing...

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very vibrant and engaging lecturer. You won't be bored in class even though it's around dinnertime on Monday evenings. He explains concepts clearly and is skilled at using humor for didactic value.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel is a great teacher! He made the class enjoyable to attend even on Monday evenings, and he was always enthusiastic about the material he was teaching. I really enjoyed having him as a teacher. In addition, he was very receptive to students and always responded to student suggestions or feedback. When students had a question in class that he could not answer, he would send out a follow-up email after he had investigated it more thoroughly. He was a great teacher who was very dedicated to this class.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel was incredibly excited about the material and enthusiastic about his students' learning.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  I love this man! One of my favorite instructors at YSPH so far. He is dynamic and interesting. He explains things incredibly well. Very complicated topics get across to students simply when Dr. Paltiel is teaching. Fantastic. Also, his passion for the course and the material is obvious.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Entertaining as well as instructive
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He's funny, and knows the content well.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Making the course more interesting.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel is a phenomenal instructor! One of the most engaging I've ever had. The course was extremely well-taught and well-organized.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Amusing and interesting lecturer, responsive to students in office hours and during discussions in class. In terms of improving, my problem was that the pace of the course was too fast/very rushed, and in such a large lecture class, I would not be willing to ask him to slow down because I know that many students are learning at a faster pace. I would recommend adding an optional discussion section with the TA once/week for those who require additional help.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel is amazing, he is brilliant and funny, I would come to lecture to be entertained and to learn at the same time. I would take any other course he is teaching because I know it will be interesting and entertaining.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  never get bored in david's class
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very accessible. Cares about comprehension. Interested in topic and shares enthusiasm. Very organized and clear about expectations.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Just awesome.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Instructor was extremely entertaining (sometimes my stomach hurt from laughing at his jokes), and at the same time was able to use his humor to engage us and make difficult concepts clearer. He also seemed very conscientious about tailoring the class based on student feedback. He is wonderful at lecturing!

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Professor Paltiel has a quirky sense of humor that does a wonderful job at maintaining the students' attention. Give the course is taught later in the evening, Professor Paltiel keeps the classroom alive with his infectious humor.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel brilliantly engages his students.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very engaging and interesting lecturer
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Passionate lecturer and made such dry material seem like fun. He was receptive to criticism.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  The instructor is very helpful and has a very special teaching style. And he is very sensitive of students' reaction and can give a response very soon.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Prof. Paltiel was simply great. He did a great job introducing very important and interesting material to students. He was funny and motivational in his delivery.I would encourage Prof. Paltiel to be careful when providing feedback to students when they participate in class. Using constructive criticism can really help get more students interested in his field.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Paltiel was engaging, professional, and clearly knew what he was doing. In addition, he lacks the ego that sometimes abounds here.His commitment to teaching is refreshing, and that speaks volumes.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  very good teacher
Instructor: A David Paltiel  very effective instructor. Nice guy as well.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Very engaging

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Professor Paltiel is a great lecturer, and does an excellent job solliciting participation from students. This is a really fun and well-taught course. The exams are challenging but rewarding, and he values his office hours and student participation as much as the classes themselves.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He was a good instructor.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Professor Paltiel is extremely engaging and fun in lecture. He makes what could otherwise be an esoteric and too-technical subject come alive, and really gets the class engaged.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Excellent professor with great response to questions. Weaknesses would be sometimes he goes over concepts too fast and people without some formal math/econ background might find it difficult to catch up.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  very smart and responsibleWould like to be his TA
Instructor: A David Paltiel  The man. Among the best YSPH has.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Engaging lecturer who knows the material very well.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  Great lecturer. Energetic. Easy to followDespite being an expert in his field, his entire lecture would be explained in lay terms so that every moment in class was used to its fullest.He often ended the class 30-40 mins early if he finished earlier.His pace was great. He was able to teach a lot in a short time
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Dr. Paltiel was very passionate about the material he was teaching. He wanted all students to develop a basic understanding of the material.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  As above:Strengths: dynamic, responsive to student requestsWeaknesses: presented difficult material too quickly, assumed that all students were capable of learning at the rate of the very best students, often left average students in the dust.

Instructor: A David Paltiel  The instructor is unable to effectively teach the material due to a lack of understanding of many students limited background or preparation for the class. When approached he tries to be helpful but is also defensive and argumentative. He also rushes through course material and does not really teach.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  He is a very enthusiastic professor. I can tell that he loves what he does and sharing his knowledge with other people.
Instructor: A David Paltiel  Professor Paltiel's teaching style was very engaging. This was a fun class to attend. I appreciated that he was accommodating with the grade structure.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Very good
I only had one interaction with Kiersten (via email) but she answered what she could promptly and alerted the professor when necessary.

The use of the TA is this class was a joke: she graded the midterms, but otherwise didn't have to do anything, but check to see if we did the homework. Why isn't there a weekly section for this class, reviewing the material, going over the homework etc. With a single lecture once a week, the course is underdone, that is, covers far less and in less detail than could be done with a better use of the TA and inclusion of a section for the class.
I don't know who is my TA.
Great! Friendly and helpful. Very willing to set up times to meet outside of office hours. Skilled at clearly explaining class information.
She seemed fine but I didn't have enough interaction to really know anything more.
Kiersten Strombotne--Kiersten was good at explaining things, friendly and patient. It wasn't really fair that there was only one office hour for 90 students.
N/a
Kristen was very helpful.
No interaction with TA during the courseshould hold more sessions to practice skills learned in class
N/A
I didn't interact with the TA a lot, so I don't really know much about her.
I didn't actually get a chance to interact with the TA and may have missed the class if he/she taught one.
I did not use her office hours, but she provided good feedback on our homework.
Good

Kiersten Strombotne: Extremely friendly and helpful during office hours, when visited for extra help. She madea point to solidify foundations in the course in a way that complemented the topics discussed in class. Responsive to emails, genuinely concerned about students' welfare and ability to succeed in the course.
not really helpful
She was excellent as responding to questions. Additionally, she was very approachable.
Helpful as needed
I would have liked more options for office hours.
I haven't seen or talked with the TA.....
I had no reason to interact with her, and she had nothing to do with the actual class period, which I was fine with.
I believe this course had a TA but with no review sessions or discussion sections its hard to say what the impact was.
She was excellent. She helped me a lot when I struggled through this class.
Never interacted with the TA
all clear in class so no need for contaction with TA
I didnt interact with her
Kiersten.Amazing TA. Took time to explain concepts. Very patient, and very knowledgeable.

Strengths: EXCELLENT grasp of the material, friendly and cared about students, willing to meet outside of office hours and outside of class, offered clear and well-organized explanations for difficult materialWeaknesses: none? The only thing I can think of is that her regular office hours were at a very inopportune time.
TA does a much better job at explaining and teaching the material.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes

This is a great class to learn basics of probability and excel modeling for decision-making. I however would not recommend it to SOM students as these topics are covered in Probability& Statistics as well as Spreadsheet Modeling.

Yes, amazing class, due to the professor, Dr. Paltiel, who is brilliant, but I wanted more: a weekly section with the TA to go over material beyond the once-weekly-lecture. I felt as I did more self-teaching in this class than others, that is, since we met only once a week, had assignments that weren't graded, the course didn't ask too much of me and then the midterm arrived and you had to cram even though it was a take home. People did well on the test, but with better use of the TA, we could have gotten more in-depth, covered more material or gotten additional support for understanding the weekly lecture.
I believe there are some useful lesson we could learn from this course.
Good intro to Cost Effective Analysis, but you'll have to spend a lot of timelearning the material on your own.

It is a good class if you are interested in the topic. The examples are very clinically focused, which is fine since you still learn the frameworks, it just won't be as directly related to topics we are used to studying.
I'd recommend it. I think anyone interested in public health should have some idea about how cost-effectiveness is calculated and what its role in public health might be. The instructor is great too.
very worthwhile and practical, it's a must-take course at YSPH!
Good class, would recommend.
Yes, would recommend
I would recommend it. Good course, gives you a good background of C/E analysis but it is not too in-depth
I would not recommend it unless it is required or restructured.
N/a
Great course to learn about decision making, cost-effectiveness especially in terms of public health applications. Very well prepared lectures, and attention-grabbing examples. Overall verygood.
great skills learned, need a little more application to perfect them
Helpful framework. Recommended.
It is one of the best courses at YSPH. Definitely recommend to take it.
No.

The class provides students with the basic knowledge of cost-effectiveness analysis through the construction of probability trees and the calculation of posterior probabilities. The class is self-taught and there are no good textbooks other than the text that the professor provides. Although the class entails calculating conditional probabilities, a student who may not be strong in math should not be dissuade to take this class.
Great course! It is a must take for every student since it provides a perspective on how to think through problems.
Super interesting material, but super hard course. Caused many tears.

One of the funnest and most interesting classes I've taken. This will definitely make you think about how you make decisions and how to compare different health programs/policies. I would absolutely recommend it to other students.

This class teaches students who to think from multiple perspectives. The homework is fun. It involves case studies, and problems are similar to brain teasers.This class will boost your IQ and make you smarter.
Good course on the basic concepts of cost-effectiveness analysis. Before the course, I had no idea what this even meant, and I now feel comfortable reading papers on the subject.

This is a great class for students who want to learn about cost-effectiveness analysis and decision-making. Although it is just an introductory class, you learn about the basics of conducting a cost-effectiveness analysis and the cases and exams are very oriented towards having you apply your knowledge. Dr. Paltiel is also a wonderful teacher who makes the information applicable and fun. I would strongly recommend this course to students.

One of my favorite courses so far. I just love the instructor. Also, the material is interesting and gets you thinking about how you would assess information regarding a decision to make the best, most cost effective one. Fantastic.
I highly recommend this course it is a different way to approach public health that is not taught in any other classes.
It's ok. I don't know why this course is a requirement. I don't know that I'll be using this information in the future. The midterm is worth a lot and is challenging, but the grading is fair.
YES
Take it! Great introduction to cost-effectiveness analysis.

Interesting overview to CEA. I would recommend the course, but suggest adding an optional weekly or bi-weekly discussion section for those who struggle with the material and accelerated pace of the lectures.
I would recommend that students take this course, it entertaining, challenging and relevant to public health all at once. An amazing course overall!
Strongly recommend
A great course to expand the way in which you think about problems involving cost and outcome. Not too much work, lectures are engaging, and exams are all take home.

This class teaches some great ways to think about health policy and decision making. Dr. Paltiel also introduces some complicated methods (Bayesian Stats, Incremental costs, etc) in a very digestible form. While I had been introduced to these methods in other classes, I really didn't understand them until he presented them(even though health policy is not exactly what I am best at.)
I would definitely recommend this course

This course has great real-world applications. I would recommend it, but would also warn students to be prepared to do a lot of independent learning. There is a lot of material to examine, but the benefits of this knowledge is definitely worth it!
The course will improve your understanding of probability and cost and the factors required in cost-benefit decision making.
An interesting course that will get you thinking about outcomes differently. It's geared more toward Med students than MPH policy students though.
Useful course and teaches you to think in ways that you might not have done so before.
Yes, definitely. Both the course and the instructor is very helpful.
Useful for students in all disciplines. Not too hard, worthwhile, for sure.
This is a fun and somewhat challenging introduction to cost effectiveness analysis, which will help you apply Econ and statistical methods to decision making.
I would recommend it
Professor Paltiel makes the class really fun to go to. Material is generally really interesting as well.
Definitely recommend this course. One of the best at YSPH for student in any concentration.
Great course!

Awesome. Take it. Only complaint I have is with the grading of the tests: they're graded by the TA in a bit of a formulaic manner. More than one way to skin a cat and in one instance the TA didn't recognize this (though Paltiel did).

The course gives a different perspective for evaluating programs, interventions, etc. by cost effectiveness. It shows how types of analysis are applied to public health. May be more suited to policy and management students, but I would recommend it for students in all divisions.

once a week lectures5 or so assignments - each take about 1.5hours at max to do after the reading is donetake home midterm - you have a week to completetake home final - you have 2 days to complete.Midterm harder than the final.Overall the best course I had in the Fall.
Great overview course to cost-effectiveness. I would recommend this course to another student.

I would recommend it for students who are focusing on management skills, but would not recommend it as a good way to master the skill of cost-effectiveness analysis. While it helped me think differently about public health problems, and did provide me some new skills (decision trees, review of probability, markov modeling, incremental cost-effectiveness analysis, etc.), I do not feel confident applying these skills in a work setting after taking this course.

This course is a good introduction to cost effectiveness. No programming skills are required or taught. I would recommend the course since it provides a strong enough understanding of the topic so that students can critically evaluate articles and other published cost effectiveness analyses.
